articles.headline: Democrats Defend Bill to Rein In Wall Street
articles.snippet: They said their legislation would protect consumers in their dealings with financial institutions while holding executives rather than taxpayers accountable.
articles.abstract: They said their legislation would protect consumers in their dealings with financial institutions while holding executives rather than taxpayers accountable.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  House Democrats defended their Wall Street regulatory overhaul on Thursday against sharp Republican criticism that it would perpetuate a bailout mentality, and they accused Republicans of aligning themselves with the financial institutions that caused the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Hamstrung by Delays, Fitbit Explains and Tries to Deliver
articles.snippet: It is a classic start-up story: entrepreneurs with a hot idea generate excitement, then run into problems making and delivering their product.
articles.abstract: It is a classic start-up story: entrepreneurs with a hot idea generate excitement, then run into problems making and delivering their product.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nicholas Cole was determined to shed a few pounds after the holiday season. So when he heard about a nifty new fitness device called the Fitbit Tracker, a wearable sensor that tracks movement, distance traveled and calories burned, he decided to take the plunge and order one.

articles.headline: Confronting High Risk and Banks
articles.snippet: The current financial crisis shows that some controversial accounting rules contributed to the problems.
articles.abstract: The current financial crisis shows that some controversial accounting rules contributed to the problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Did accounting help cause the financial crisis?

articles.headline: Goldman’s Curbs on Bonuses Aim to Quell Uproar
articles.snippet: It’s unclear if the move, which comes ahead of rulings by the government’s compensation czar, will placate critics.
articles.abstract: It’s unclear if the move, which comes ahead of rulings by the government’s compensation czar, will placate critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: With France joining Britain in proposing a steep tax on bank bonuses, Goldman Sachs moved on Thursday to quell the uproar over its resurgent profits and pay.

articles.headline: Many See the VAT Option as a Cure for Deficits
articles.snippet: Runaway deficits have thrust a politically unsavory savior into the spotlight: a tax on goods and services.
articles.abstract: Runaway deficits have thrust a politically unsavory savior into the spotlight: a tax on goods and services.
articles.lead_paragraph: Runaway federal deficits have thrust a politically unsavory savior into the spotlight: a nationwide tax on goods and services.

articles.headline: Blackwater Guards Tied to Secret C.I.A. Raids
articles.snippet: The guards’ involvement blurred the lines dividing the C.I.A., the military and the private security company.
articles.abstract: The guards’ involvement blurred the lines dividing the C.I.A., the military and the private security company.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Private security guards from Blackwater Worldwide participated in some of the C.I.A.’s most sensitive activities  clandestine raids with agency officers against people suspected of being insurgents in Iraq and Afghanistan and the transporting of detainees, according to former company employees and intelligence officials.
articles.byline: By James Risen and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Livening Up a Staid Magazine
articles.snippet: Gird yourselves, Harvard deans: the Harvard Business Review is getting a little more lively, beginning with the January/February issue.
articles.abstract: Gird yourselves, Harvard deans: the Harvard Business Review is getting a little more lively, beginning with the January/February issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like the university it springs from, Harvard Business Review has been all about sober tradition. Modernity? Pah! Harvard Business Review has remained fairly constant over its almost 90-year history, with long articles that gave frameworks for managing and understanding businesses. Like an academic journal, it listed its contents on its cover, and only in 1990 did it allow the first cover illustration.

articles.headline: Britain, Long a Libel Mecca, Reviews Laws
articles.snippet: England’s libel laws, which favor complainants, are under attack from publishers, scientists and others.
articles.abstract: England’s libel laws, which favor complainants, are under attack from publishers, scientists and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  England has long been a mecca for aggrieved people from around the world who want to sue for libel. Russian oligarchs, Saudi businessmen, multinational corporations, American celebrities  all have made their way to London’s courts, where jurisdiction is easy to obtain and libel laws are heavily weighted in favor of complainants.

articles.headline: Retail Data Shows Strong Start to Holiday Season
articles.snippet: The figures reinforced expectations of a modest rise in consumer spending over the next few months.
articles.abstract: The figures reinforced expectations of a modest rise in consumer spending over the next few months.
articles.lead_paragraph: A strong start to the holiday shopping season pushed retail sales higher in November, the government reported on Friday, propelling stock prices near their recent highs.

articles.headline: Steps to Take Before Cobra Subsidy Ends
articles.snippet: A federal subsidy has allowed laid-off workers to keep up with health insurance premiums. But that subsidy is about to expire.
articles.abstract: A federal subsidy has allowed laid-off workers to keep up with health insurance premiums. But that subsidy is about to expire.
articles.lead_paragraph: Roberta Mason, 63, of Turner, Me., is one of millions of people who are finding themselves in a special kind of health insurance bind  or will soon.
